explanation:
Why each symbol is required for checking the MISRA 'for loop shall be well-formed' rule for OS_CondVarCreate:

- OS_CHECK_POINTER (macro): This macro is used in the function body and is expanded inline. Macros can contain for-loops or control-flow that become part of the function textually; the analyser must see its expansion to confirm there are no for-loops (or to check any for-loops are well-formed).

- OS_CHECK_APINAME (macro): As above, this macro may expand into code that iterates (e.g. string validation or copy loops). Its expansion must be inspected since any for-loop inside will be part of the target function for MISRA analysis.

- OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew (function): Called directly by the target. Even though it is a separate function, if it is implemented as a macro/inline or otherwise expanded in some builds, or if its documentation/implementation affects loop variables used later, its body may be relevant. At minimum its implementation should be reviewed in case it contains for-loops that are textually inlined or that interact with loop counters/flags in this function.

- OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew (function): Finalizes the new object id and is called in this function. Same rationale as ObjectIdAllocateNew — check its implementation for any for-loops or side effects that could relate to loop counters/flags used in OS_CondVarCreate (or if it can be inlined/macros).

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET (macro): This macro is used to obtain 'condvar'. If it expands to code performing iteration (e.g. index checking loops) those loops would be part of OS_CondVarCreate and must be examined.

- OS_OBJECT_INIT (macro): Used to initialize the table entry and save the name. Very likely to perform a name copy or initialization that could use a loop (e.g. copying into obj_name). Its expansion must be inspected to determine whether it contains any for-loops and whether those loops meet MISRA requirements (single counter, no side-effects, etc.).

- OS_CondVarCreate_Impl (function): Called while the object type is locked, and the comment says it “reads info from the table.” If that call is implemented as inline or calls functions/macros that are used inside a for-loop context, its implementation should be examined. Additionally, if OS_OBJECT_INIT or other macros call this implementation inline or as part of larger macro expansions, its loops (if any) may be relevant.

- OS_object_token_t (typedef/struct): The token variable is passed by reference to some macros/functions. The layout/type may determine what fields are accessed/modified by macros (e.g. OS_OBJECT_INIT) and whether those operations use loops over token fields.

- OS_condvar_internal_record_t (typedef/struct): The condvar pointer type is manipulated by macros (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_OBJECT_INIT). Its member types (notably obj_name) and sizes determine whether name initialization uses loops and what loop counters/types would be used.

- obj_name (field of OS_condvar_internal_record_t): OS_OBJECT_INIT saves the var_name into obj_name — that copy is the most likely place for a loop (character-by-character copy). The analyser must inspect the code that writes obj_name to confirm any for-loop there is well-formed (only one counter, counter-only modification in third clause, no persistent side-effects in second clause, etc.).

- OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR (constant): Passed to OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew; include for completeness to locate the correct code-path or specialization (the allocator may behave differently per object type and different paths could contain different loops).

- OS_SUCCESS (constant): Return value checked; included to help locate conditional branches in the caller that might affect inlining or macro expansions (to ensure the correct code path is analysed for possible for-loops).

- osal_id_t, int32, uint32 (typedefs): The function uses these integral types. Knowing their exact typedefs (signedness/width) can be necessary when checking loop counter types and whether the loop counter is a suitable/inappropriate type per MISRA constraints (e.g. if a loop counter is declared with a type that is not appropriate or is modified elsewhere).

Notes:
- The focus is on macros that expand inline into OS_CondVarCreate and any inline/inlineable functions; these are the places where for-loops could become part of the target function textually. Regular non-inlined callee functions that contain for-loops do not by themselves make the target function violate the MISRA for-loop rule unless such functions are called from within a for-loop in the target function; still, their implementations are often inspected by a verifier and may be included if inlining or code-generation could merge them into the target.
- If you want a deeper reachability scan (to include every indirect callee that might be inlined or macro-expanded), add OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit, OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch, OS_ObjectIdFindNextFree, OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel, OS_NotifyEvent, and any string-copy helpers used by OS_OBJECT_INIT (e.g. strncpy/strcpy wrappers).
